title: The Complete Gravel Racing Training Guide
subtitle: Everything you need to know about gravel racing — from gear to training to race day execution.
meta_description: The complete gravel racing guide: training fundamentals, nutrition, race week protocol, and post-race recovery. Free chapters covering gear, race selection, and training basics.

blocks.content:
Gravel racing is riding bikes on unpaved roads for distances ranging from "aggressive Saturday ride" to "questioning your life choices."

The routes are typically 30-200+ miles of dirt, gravel, sand, crushed limestone, fire roads, and occasionally pavement when the route designer runs out of worse options. The surfaces vary from smooth hardpack (fast) to chunky limestone (slow and punishing) to sandy two-track (pray your tires hold air).

Here's what makes gravel different from road racing or mountain biking:

It's more accessible than road racing. No peloton politics, no sketchy criteriums where one crash takes out 40 people, no unwritten rules about who's allowed to attack when. You show up, you ride, you finish (or don't). The person who wins and the person who finishes last both rode the same course, faced the same challenges, and earned their finish.

It's less technical than mountain biking. You're not navigating rock gardens or launching off drops. Most gravel courses are rideable by anyone with basic bike handling skills and reasonable fitness. The bike does matter, but not as much as road racing where a 30-second gap becomes insurmountable. On gravel, you can have a mechanical, fix it, and still chase back.

It's self-sufficient. Aid stations exist but they're 25-40 miles apart and might run out of what you need. You carry your own food, your own tools, your own flat kit. When something breaks, you fix it. When you bonk, it's because you didn't eat enough. The race doesn't owe you anything.

The spectrum is wide. You can sign up for a 40-mile "fun ride" distance at most events and just enjoy being outside with a bunch of other people who also thought riding on dirt was a good idea. Or you can sign up for the 200-mile suffer fest and find out what you're made of. Both are valid. Both are gravel racing.
The culture rewards suffering, but it doesn't require heroics. Finishing counts. How you finish is between you and your ego.

Before choosing a race or a training plan, figure out what you actually want from this experience. These four categories aren't judgments—they're honest descriptions of how much time and ambition you're bringing to the table.

tabs.label: Ayahuasca
tabs.title: The Ayahuasca (0-5 hrs/week)
tabs.content:
Instead of therapy, Ayahuascas use gravel cycling as a tool to cope by inducing a borderline psychedelic experience through physical exertion. They accomplish this by signing up for something so insane that a psychic break is all but guaranteed, don't train for an event at all, or both.

**Training reality:** 0-5 hours per week. You're underprepared by conventional standards and you know it. Plans for this category are damage control—getting you to the finish line when time isn't on your side.

tabs.label: Finisher
tabs.title: The Finisher (5-12 hrs/week)
tabs.content:
Finishers are usually inspired by the marketing campaigns of Big Gravel events like [Unbound 200](/race/unbound-200/) or [Leadville 100](/race/leadville-100/). Their goal is simple: finish the damn thing. Some want to maximize fun without pushing too hard. Others want to finish strong and proud, not just survive.

**Training reality:** 5-12 hours per week. You're building enough base to finish strong. You'll train with purpose but you're not giving up your weekends or social life entirely.

tabs.label: Competitor
tabs.title: The Competitor (12-18 hrs/week)
tabs.content:
Competitors are finishers who got bored after finishing, and instead of quitting like someone sane, they decided to do the events again—faster. The category ranges from individuals who just want to beat their own past times to those who want to win but lack some combination of training time, talent, or skill.

**Training reality:** 12-18 hours per week. You're training seriously. This volume typically places you in the top third of the field. You're not just participating—you're competing.

tabs.label: Podium
tabs.title: The Podium (18-25+ hrs/week)
tabs.content:
These riders are fast enough to win or stand on the podium. Unless this is a low-key event with few sign-ups, performing at this level requires preparation that all the other categories can't even imagine. For all but the most physically gifted, being in the podium category is an all-consuming part-time job.

**Training reality:** 18-25+ hours per week. At Tier 1 races with international fields, this is what it takes to compete at the front. This is not recreational cycling—this is serious training.

blocks.content: Most readers are Finishers or Competitors. If you were a Podium, you wouldn't be reading an introductory guide. If you were an Ayahuasca, you wouldn't want to decrease the chances of having an out-of-body experience by preparing better.

The gravel industry wants you to believe you need a $12,000 bike with electronic shifting, carbon everything, and aerodynamic optimization to ride on dirt roads.

You don't.

You need a bike that fits, tires that don't suck, gearing that lets you climb without walking, and the fitness to pedal it for hours. Everything else is optimization you can worry about after you've finished your first few races.

What you actually need:

blocks.caption: Essential Gravel Gear
rows: Any bike with drop bars, clearance for 38mm+ tires
Gravel demands tire clearance more than aero gains
Wide tires = comfort + traction. Tubeless = fewer flats
Low gear under 1:1 ratio (e.g., 32x34 or easier)
Steep climbs on loose gravel require spinning, not mashing
Anything alloy that holds air and stays true
Durability matters more than 200g weight savings
Carbon wheels (unless you crash a lot and enjoy expensive repairs)
Bars that are comfortable for 6+ hours, flared drops help
Gravel riding is long. Comfort beats aero
Fancy carbon bars, built-in computer mounts
Don't change saddles before a race
Trendy cutout designs you haven't tested
Clipless or flats you're comfortable with
Switching from flats to clipless 2 weeks before race day

blocks.caption: Realistic First-Season Setup Costs
rows: Buy fit + function first. Used alloy with decent wheels is fine.
Do NOT cheap out on head protection.
SPD pedals + mid-tier XC shoes last for years.
One good bib > three trash ones.
Saddle bag, tube, CO₂/pump, plugs, multitool, tire levers.
Used Wahoo / Garmin is fine. Needs mapping + power support.
Single-sided pedal PM is a great entry point.
Deals + patience can cut this further.

blocks.content: If money is tight, spend in this order: (1) Fit + function on the bike, (2) decent bibs and a modern helmet, (3) head unit + budget power meter. Hunt used on local classifieds, FB groups, Pro's Closet, or friends "upgrading." Last year's head units and single-sided power meters are stupid-good value.

items.title: Bottles and Storage
items.content: Two bottle cages minimum (three if bike allows). Jersey pockets for food (gels, bars, real food). Frame bag or bento box only if racing 100+ miles (otherwise they're just in the way).

items.title: Repair Kit (Mandatory)
items.content:
Spare tube (even if tubeless). Tire plug kit + CO2 or mini pump. Multi-tool with chain breaker. Quick link for your chain. Tire levers.

If you can't fix a flat in under 10 minutes, practice until you can.

blocks.content: Here's what actually matters, in order. Fitness determines {{70}}% of your result. Everything else fights over the remaining {{30}}%:

items.label: Fitness
items.detail: Costs nothing. Requires time and discipline. Determines 70% of your result.

items.label: Pacing and Execution
items.detail: Free. Determines 20% of your result. You can be fit and blow up by going out too hard.

items.label: Nutrition
items.detail: Cheap. Determines 8% of your result. Bonking loses races.

items.label: Bike Handling
items.detail: Free (just requires practice). Determines 1.5% of your result.

items.label: Equipment
items.detail: Expensive. Determines 0.5% of your result (unless your equipment is broken or wildly inappropriate).

blocks.content:
You can buy your way from 95% to 95.5%. You can't buy your way from 70% to 95%.

The corollary: if you're not already fast on a mediocre bike, a better bike won't make you fast. It'll make you a slower rider on a nicer bike.
Get fit first. Get good at suffering. Get comfortable riding on unpredictable surfaces for hours. Then worry about whether your crankset saves 40 grams.

blocks.question: A rider upgrades from an aluminum bike to a $12,000 carbon setup but doesn't change their training. What's the most likely outcome?

options.text: Significant time savings from the lighter, more aerodynamic bike
Marginal improvement (~0.5%) because equipment determines very little of the result
Slower times because carbon bikes are harder to handle on gravel

blocks.explanation: Equipment determines roughly 0.5% of your result. Fitness (70%) and pacing (20%) dwarf equipment gains. A strong rider on a mediocre bike will humiliate a mediocre rider on a $12k spaceship.

sections.title: What You're Actually Signing Up For

blocks.content:
Gravel racing demands:

**An aerobic engine.** These races are long. Even the short ones. You'll be riding for 2-12 hours depending on distance and your fitness. This isn't about peak power. It's about sustainable output for extended duration.

**Basic bike handling.** You need to corner on loose surfaces, descend without death-gripping your bars, and climb seated on inconsistent traction. None of this is technical by mountain bike standards, but it's not Tour de France smooth roads either.

**Self-sufficiency.** Aid stations exist, but they're far apart and they run out of things. You carry your own food, fix your own mechanicals, manage your own pacing. The race gives you a route. Everything else is your responsibility.

**Mental resilience.** Not toughness. Resilience. Everyone wants to quit at some point. The difference between finishing and DNF-ing is often just continuing to pedal when your brain is screaming at you to stop. You don't need to be fearless. You just need to be stubborn.

Gravel racing is accessible. You don't need to be a pro cyclist. You don't need a perfect bike. You don't need special genetics.

You need:

- A bike that fits and doesn't break
- The fitness to ride it for hours
- The discipline to train consistently
- The sense to fuel properly and pace conservatively

Everything else is optimization.

If you have those four things, you can finish a gravel race. Whether you finish in 6 hours or 12 hours is between you and your training plan.

Up next: [Chapter 2](#race-selection) helps you choose the right race using the Gravel God scoring system. Then [Chapter 3](#training-fundamentals) breaks down how training actually works—zones, phases, and the adaptation cycle that drives all fitness gains.

Not all gravel races are created equal. Some are iconic suffer-fests with 10,000 feet of climbing and national-level competition. Others are well-organized local events with pancake-flat routes and a beer garden at the finish.

Both are valid. But they require different preparation.

The problem: most race websites oversell their difficulty and prestige. Every event claims to be "epic" and "world-class." You need an objective framework to evaluate what you're actually signing up for.

The Gravel God Race Ranking System scores every race across 14 dimensions — 7 measuring the course itself, 7 measuring the race experience. Each dimension is scored 1-5 by human editors, then the total is normalized to a 0-100 scale.

No algorithms. No sponsors. No pay-to-play. Just editorial judgment applied consistently across 328 races.

Every race is evaluated across two categories of seven dimensions each. Course dimensions measure what the terrain demands of your body. Editorial dimensions measure the quality, prestige, and overall experience of the event.

The 14 dimension scores (each 1-5) are summed, then normalized: (sum / 70) × 100 = overall score. That score determines tier placement.

tabs.label: Tier 1 — Elite
tabs.title: Tier 1 — Elite (Score 80+)
tabs.content:
The marquee events. High difficulty, high prestige, national or international competition. These races define the gravel calendar — the ones people plan their season around, the ones with waitlists and lottery systems. Finishing a Tier 1 event means something.

If you're targeting a Tier 1 race, you need specific, structured preparation. General fitness won't cut it.

**When to race them:** As event two or three, not as a first gravel race. You want experience and fitness before throwing down thousands of dollars and months of training for one of these. Build up through smaller races first, then tackle the monuments when you know what you're doing.

**Examples:** [Unbound 200](/race/unbound-200/), [SBT GRVL](/race/steamboat-gravel/), [Badlands](/race/badlands/)

tabs.label: Tier 2 — Contender
tabs.title: Tier 2 — Contender (Score 60-79)
tabs.content:
Serious races with strong regional or national followings. Well-organized, challenging courses, meaningful competition at the front. Not quite iconic but respected. You'll see fast riders, solid production value, and courses that demand proper preparation.

Tier 2 races reward training but don't require elite-level specificity. A good general endurance plan with race-specific intensity will get you there.

**When to race them:** Sweet spot for ambitious first-timers with an endurance background and serious competitors who want quality without the full circus.

**Examples:** [Gravel Locos](/race/gravel-locos/), [Whiskey Off-Road](/race/whiskey-off-road/), [Unbound 100](/race/unbound-100/)

tabs.label: Tier 3 — Solid
tabs.title: Tier 3 — Solid (Score 45-59)
tabs.content:
Good races that are well-executed and locally popular but don't draw national fields. Still challenging, still worth training for, just without the prestige or hype. These are the backbone of the gravel calendar — consistent, reliable, fun.

Great for building race experience. You can show up with solid general fitness and have a good day.

**When to race them:** Ideal first gravel race for most people. Lower stakes, easier logistics, still a real challenge.

**Examples:** [Croatan Buck Fifty](/race/croatan-buck-fifty/), [Iron Horse Bicycle Classic](/race/iron-horse-bicycle-classic/)

tabs.label: Tier 4 — Roster
tabs.title: Tier 4 — Roster (Score Under 45)
tabs.content:
Beginner-friendly, less physically demanding, or primarily social events. Nothing wrong with these — they're entry points and fun adventures. Great for first-timers, social riders, or anyone who just wants to be outside on bikes without the pressure.

No specific training plan needed. Just ride your bike regularly and show up.

**When to race them:** Great if you want to dip a toe in without the full commitment. Also great for recovery races or just enjoying bikes with friends in a semi-structured format.

**Examples:** [Albia Holy Cow](/race/albia-holy-cow/), [Cedar Blitz](/race/cedar-blitz/)

blocks.question: A first-time gravel racer with a solid endurance background (runs marathons, rides centuries) wants to pick their first event. Which tier range is the best starting point?

options.text: Tier 1 — go big or go home, the experience will be worth it
Tier 2-3 — serious enough to challenge you, without the full logistical and financial commitment of a monument
Tier 4 only — always start at the easiest level regardless of background

blocks.explanation: Tier 2-3 events offer meaningful challenge with more forgiving logistics. With an endurance background, you have the base fitness to handle a real gravel race. Save Tier 1 for when you've got a season of gravel-specific experience. Tier 4 might be too easy and not representative of what gravel racing actually demands.
