Once you've picked your race, [Chapter 3](#training-fundamentals) covers how training actually works—the adaptation cycle, zones, and periodization that will get you to the start line ready.

Before you start executing workouts, you need to understand how training works at a mechanical level.

Not theory for theory's sake—practical understanding that changes how you approach every session, how you structure your week, and how you respond when your body doesn't cooperate.

This chapter builds from first principles: the adaptation cycle that drives all fitness gains, the zones that define intensity, the variables you manipulate to create training stress, the phases that organize your 12 weeks, and the philosophical approaches that match different athlete types.

Start here. [Chapter 4](#workout-execution) covers how to actually execute these workouts, and [Chapter 5](#nutrition-fueling) covers the fuel system that makes it all work.

sections.title: The Foundational Model: How Adaptation Works

blocks.content: All training follows the same basic cycle. Understanding this cycle is the difference between training intelligently and just accumulating fatigue.

steps.label: Stress
steps.content: You apply training stress—a hard workout that exceeds your current capacity. This creates disruption: muscle fibers develop microtears, glycogen stores deplete, metabolic waste accumulates, cellular damage occurs. Your body registers this as a problem that needs solving.

steps.label: Fatigue
steps.content: Immediately after training, you're weaker than before you started. Your muscles are damaged. Your fuel tanks are empty. Your nervous system is taxed. If you tested your FTP right after a hard interval session, it would be lower than your rested FTP. This is normal. Fatigue is the signal that triggers adaptation.

steps.label: Recovery
steps.content: Given adequate rest, nutrition, and time, your body initiates repair: muscle fibers rebuild, mitochondria multiply, capillary density increases, glycogen storage expands, neurological efficiency improves. Timeline: 24-48 hours for muscle repair, 3-7 days for mitochondrial adaptation, 2-4 weeks for new baseline fitness.

steps.label: Supercompensation
steps.content: If recovery is complete, your body doesn't just return to baseline—it overshoots. Your body builds slightly more capacity than it had before to handle similar stress more easily next time. You're now stronger than you were before the workout.

steps.label: Apply New Stress
steps.content: Once you've adapted, you apply a slightly larger stress. The cycle repeats. Over weeks and months, these small adaptations compound into meaningful fitness gains.

blocks.question: What happens if you apply new training stress before recovery is complete?

options.text: You get faster because you're training harder
You accumulate fatigue without adaptation — digging a hole, not building fitness
Your body skips to supercompensation faster

blocks.explanation: Insufficient recovery is the most common training mistake. Without complete recovery, you never reach the supercompensation phase. You're just piling fatigue on top of fatigue.

blocks.content:
**The Practical Rules:**

1. **Training stress must be adequate but not excessive** — Hard enough to trigger adaptation. Not so hard you can't recover.
2. **Recovery must be prioritized as much as training** — Sleep, nutrition, stress management—these aren't optional. They're where adaptation happens.
3. **Consistency compounds** — Ten weeks of steady training beats four weeks of heroics followed by injury or burnout.
4. **Fitness is cumulative** — Every completed workout adds to the total. Missed workouts don't just subtract—they prevent compounding.
5. **Patience is required** — Meaningful adaptation takes weeks and months, not days. Trust the process.

sections.title: Training Zones: What They Mean and How to Use Them

blocks.content:
Every workout prescription includes a zone target. Here's what they mean and how to use them.

Zones exist to quantify intensity and give you a common language for prescribing workouts.

But here's the paradox: the end goal of measuring intensity is to help you develop a *feeling* for intensity. You use power meters, heart rate monitors, and zone charts to develop an intuitive sense of effort. Because despite our best efforts, the human body remains too complex to neatly summarize with device-generated data. Your subjective feeling is infinitely more valuable than numbered outputs based on incomplete data collection, reductive models, and population-level assumptions.

You're a special snowflake. Learn your snowflake.

blocks.caption: Master Zone Chart
rows: Very easy, relaxed pace. Gentle spinning—feels like nothing. Full conversation possible.
All-day pace—sustainable and steady. Can chat freely. This is where you should spend MOST of your training time.
Comfortably hard. Breathing deeper but rhythmic. Talking in short sentences. Sustainable for 1-2 hours.
Uncomfortably sustainable. Hard enough to hurt, easy enough to repeat. Where you'll spend most of a gravel race.
Hard, controlled effort. Only a few words at a time. 10-30 minute blocks.
Very hard, heavy breathing. Near maximum. 2-8 minute efforts.
Sharp, explosive efforts—30 seconds to 3 minutes max. All-out.
All-out sprints. Pure explosive power. Lasts only seconds.

cards.back: Active Recovery: <55% FTP. Very easy, gentle spinning. Feels like nothing.
Endurance: 56-75% FTP. All-day pace. Can chat freely. Where you spend MOST of training time.
Tempo: 76-87% FTP. Comfortably hard. Breathing deeper but rhythmic. Sustainable for 1-2 hours.
Gravel Race Pace: 88-92% FTP. Uncomfortably sustainable. Where you'll spend most of a gravel race.
Lactate Threshold: 93-105% FTP. Hard, controlled effort. 10-30 minute blocks.
VO2max: 106-120% FTP. Very hard, heavy breathing. 2-8 minute efforts.
Anaerobic Capacity: 121-150% FTP. Sharp, explosive efforts lasting 30 seconds to 3 minutes.
Neuromuscular Power: >150% FTP. All-out sprints lasting only seconds. Pure explosive power.

tabs.label: Why G Spot?
tabs.title: Why G Spot, Not Sweet Spot?
tabs.content:
We call it G Spot instead, and it's not just branding:

**1. It's more intensity-specific to gravel racing** — Sweet Spot (88-93% FTP) is too high for most gravel races. Actual race data shows most gravel racers spend the majority of their time at 87-90% FTP. G Spot (88-92%) better matches reality.

**2. It's better for training execution** — Sweet Spot intervals at 90-93% FTP have a nasty habit of turning into threshold intervals. G Spot's lower ceiling (92% max) keeps you honest.

**3. It's equally as scientific** — Frank Overton pointed at a unitless graph showing two theoretical curves and called it science. Two can play that game. G Spot is calibrated to actual gravel race power data.

**4. It's better named, objectively** — "Sweet Spot" sounds like something your grandmother would say about a parking space.

tabs.label: Three Systems
tabs.title: Three Measurement Systems
tabs.content:
You'll see three metrics in your workouts:

**Power (% of FTP)** — The most precise. Measures actual work output in watts.

**Heart Rate (% of HRmax)** — Secondary system. Lags power by 1-3 minutes, affected by heat, hydration, fatigue, stress, caffeine. Useful for pacing long efforts.

**RPE (Rate of Perceived Exertion, 1-10 scale)** — Your subjective experience. The ultimate arbiter. If the numbers say one thing but your body says another, trust your body.

**How to set your zones:**

- **FTP:** 20-minute all-out test, multiply average power by 0.95
- **HRmax:** 211 - (0.64 × age). Example: age 38 = 186 bpm
- **RPE:** Practice correlating numbers with feeling

tabs.label: Critical Notes
tabs.title: Critical Notes on Zone Use
tabs.content:
**1. Zones are descriptive, not prescriptive** — They describe what you did, not rigid targets.

**2. Easy means easy** — Most people train too hard on easy days. Zone 2 should feel conversational.

**3. RPE is the ultimate arbiter** — Power meters can lie. Heart rate can be misleading. Your body doesn't lie.

**4. FTP changes slowly** — Don't retest every week. Test at Week 1, optionally Week 6-7, and before your race.

**5. Heart rate lags power** — Use power for short, hard efforts. Use heart rate for pacing long endurance rides.

**6. Anaerobically gifted athletes are different** — The percentages assume average physiology. If you're exceptional, your coach will adjust zones.

blocks.title: Your Personal Zone Calculator
blocks.description: Enter your FTP or 20-minute test power to see your training zones.

blocks.content:
When you manipulate training, you're adjusting three variables: **frequency** (how often), **duration** (how long), and **intensity** (how hard). These create *training load*—the total stress applied to your system.

Thanks to really smart people we can quantify training stress precisely:

blocks.caption: Key Training Load Metrics
rows: Training Stress Score — quantifies total stress of a workout
Lets you compare workouts. 90-min tempo and 60-min VO2max can both = ~80 TSS
Chronic Training Load (42-day average TSS) — your fitness
Higher CTL = more fitness. Builds slowly (+3-5 pts/week)
Acute Training Load (7-day average TSS) — your fatigue
High ATL = fresh fatigue. Responds quickly to training changes
Negative = building fitness. Race day target: +15 to +25

steps.label: Base (Weeks 1-4)
steps.content: Establish aerobic foundation. 70-85% volume in Z1-Z2. CTL rising steadily (+3-5/wk). TSB slightly negative (-5 to -15). Week 4 = recovery week (60% volume). Feels boring but doable—you should finish most rides feeling like you could do more.

steps.label: Build (Weeks 5-10)
steps.content: Layer intensity, develop race-specific fitness. 60-70% Z1-Z2, 30-40% Z3-Z6. Two to three quality sessions per week. The magic happens here: deliberately dig a fatigue hole (TSB goes to -25), recover just enough, then dig another hole. This is where fitness sharpens.

steps.label: Peak/Taper (Weeks 11-12)
steps.content: Shed fatigue, maintain sharpness. Volume drops 30-50%. Intensity stays high but duration decreases. Week 11: TSB rises to +5 to +10. Week 12: TSB targets +15 to +25 for race day. Fitness doesn't improve—the goal is to remove the fatigue layer so you can express the fitness you've built.

tabs.label: Pyramidal
tabs.title: Traditional Pyramidal Periodization
tabs.content:
**Structure:** Big aerobic base → add tempo → add threshold → add VO2max → taper

**Distribution:** ~80% Z1-Z2, ~15% Z3-Z4, ~5% Z5-Z6

**Best for:** Finisher Beginner, Ayahuasca Beginner (with endurance background)

Conservative, progressive, teaches proper training structure. Low injury risk. CTL builds gradually and steadily.

tabs.label: Polarized
tabs.title: Polarized Training (80/20)
tabs.content:
**Structure:** 80% easy (Z1-Z2) + 20% hard (Z4-Z6), very little Z3

**Best for:** Finisher Intermediate, Compete Intermediate, Masters Intermediate

Maximizes adaptation by keeping easy days truly easy (full recovery) and hard days truly hard (maximum stimulus). Well-researched, proven across endurance sports. Requires discipline to keep easy days easy.

tabs.label: HIIT
tabs.title: HIIT-Focused / Reverse Periodization
tabs.content:
**Structure:** Intensity first → volume later (opposite of traditional)

**Distribution:** ~50% Z1-Z2, ~50% Z4-Z6

**Best for:** Ayahuasca Intermediate, Ayahuasca Beginner (with caution)

Maximizes fitness gains from minimal time. High injury risk if athlete lacks base fitness. Mentally and physically draining.

tabs.label: Block
tabs.title: Block Periodization
tabs.content:
**Structure:** Concentrated blocks of specific work separated by recovery

**Example:** 2-week threshold block → recovery week → 2-week VO2 block → recovery week

**Best for:** Finisher Advanced, Compete Advanced

Creates deep adaptation by focusing on one system at a time. ATL spikes dramatically during blocks, then drops during recovery. Requires strong base fitness.

tabs.label: GOAT
tabs.title: GOAT Method (Gravel-Optimized Adaptive Training)
tabs.content:
**Structure:** Polarized base + block build + race-specific sharpening

**Best for:** Compete Intermediate/Advanced, Podium Advanced

Gravel-specific. Builds both aerobic engine and anaerobic capacity. Balances volume and intensity for variable terrain. Requires experience to execute properly.

blocks.content:
Your plan already incorporates the right philosophy for your category and level. You don't need to choose—it's built in.

What you need to do now is execute.

chapters.title: Workout Execution
chapters.subtitle: Or: How to Actually Do the Damn Workouts

blocks.content:
You've got a plan. You understand the fundamentals from [Chapter 3](#training-fundamentals). You know what the zones mean.

None of that matters if you can't execute the workouts correctly.

Most people fail training plans not because the programming is bad but because they don't know how to translate "3×15 min @ 95% FTP" into an actual ride that builds fitness instead of just accumulating fatigue.

This chapter covers execution: how to do different workout types, what to do when things go wrong, how to adjust on the fly, and the recovery protocols that make tomorrow's workout possible.

There's a massive gap between what's written on the plan and what actually happens.

**The plan says:** "Tuesday: 3×15 min threshold @ 95-100% FTP, 8 min recovery between intervals"

**What actually happens:**

- You skip the warmup because you're running late
- Interval 1: You go out at 105% FTP because you feel good
- Interval 2: You're struggling to hold 95%, questioning your FTP
- Interval 3: You bail at 10 minutes because you're cooked
- You skip the cooldown and immediately start checking Instagram

**Result:** Incomplete workout, accumulated fatigue, no meaningful adaptation, compromised recovery for Wednesday's ride.

This chapter teaches you how to close that gap.

items.label: Warm Up Properly
items.detail: For endurance: 10-15 min Z1→Z2. For intensity: 15-20 min Z1→Z2→Z3 with 3×1 min openers. Cold muscles don't produce power efficiently.

items.label: Do the Actual Workout (Not More, Not Less)
items.detail: Execute what's prescribed. Not more. Not less. Trust the plan. Adding volume or intensity might feel productive, but it accumulates fatigue, compromises recovery, and ruins tomorrow's workout.

items.label: Chase Time-in-Zone, Not Hero Intervals
items.detail: Goal: highest average power across the entire set. Start conservatively. Finish strong. Complete the set. Bad: 320W/290W/270W/Failed. Good: 300W/300W/295W/295W.

items.label: Stop If Power Drops >10%
items.detail: Quality beats quantity. Four quality intervals at 300W beats six degraded intervals averaging 270W.

tabs.label: Z2 Endurance
tabs.title: Z2 (Endurance) — The Foundation
tabs.content:
**Target:** 56-75% FTP, RPE 3-4, conversational

Ride steady, no surges. Should feel easy enough to go for hours. Full sentences possible. Nose breathing (if you can't, you're too hard).

**Common mistakes:** Drifting into Z3 because you're bored. Turning every endurance ride into a tempo ride. Riding with faster friends and getting pulled up.

**The fix:** Discipline. Easy means easy. This is 70-80% of your training volume. Protect it.

tabs.label: G Spot
tabs.title: G Spot (88-92% FTP) — Gravel Race Pace
tabs.content:
**Target:** 88-92% FTP, RPE 6-7, "uncomfortably sustainable"

Stay seated, control breathing. Hard enough to hurt, easy enough to repeat. Could talk in short phrases but wouldn't want to. Fuel properly: 60-80g carbs/hour.

**Common mistakes:** Pushing into threshold (93%+). Not fueling adequately.

**Success looks like:** All intervals completed, power stable ±5%, RPE 6-7, feeling like you could do one more if forced.

tabs.label: Threshold
tabs.title: Threshold (93-105% FTP) — FTP Development
tabs.content:
**Target:** 95-100% FTP, RPE 7-8

Goal: 30-60 min total time-in-zone. Even intervals (2×20, 3×15, 4×12) beat one heroic 40-minute effort. Start at 95%, build into rhythm. Recovery: 5-10 min Z1 between intervals.

**Success looks like:** All intervals completed at target, power consistent (±3%), RPE 7-8, interval 3 felt hardest but you finished strong.

tabs.label: VO2max
tabs.title: VO2max (110-120% FTP) — Raising the Ceiling
tabs.content:
**Target:** 110-120% FTP, RPE 9, gasping, burning legs, maximal but repeatable

Warm-up is critical: 20-25 min progressive with 3×1 min openers. Hit the target from the start. Full recovery between: 4-5 min Z1, HR must drop below 60% max. Stop if power drops >10%.

**Success looks like:** 4-5 quality intervals at target power, RPE 9 throughout, completed the set without falling apart.

items.title: Scenario 1: You Feel Like Shit
items.content:
**Symptoms:** Sleep was bad, work was stressful, legs feel dead before you start

**What to do:** Reduce intensity by 5-10%. Shorten intervals if needed. Prioritize completion over heroics. Swap intensity for endurance if you're really cooked.

**What not to do:** Push through and accumulate junk volume that compromises recovery.

items.title: Scenario 2: You Can't Hit Power Targets
items.content:
**Symptoms:** Interval 1 feels way harder than it should, power is 10W+ below target

**Possible causes:** Stale FTP, inadequate recovery, illness brewing, equipment issues

**What to do:** Check equipment first. Drop power 5% and see if effort matches RPE. If still struggling, abort and take a rest day. Retest FTP if this happens multiple sessions in a row.

items.title: Scenario 3: Life Happens (Missed Workouts)
items.content:
**What to do:** Don't double up to "make up" missed sessions. Don't panic and add volume. Execute the next workout as scheduled. One missed workout doesn't ruin your plan.

**What not to do:** Try to cram two days into one. That just digs a deeper hole.

blocks.content:
**Green light (execute as written):** Good sleep, resting HR normal, feeling motivated, body feels fresh.

**Yellow light (reduce intensity 5-10%):** Sleep was okay but not great, slight fatigue, moderate motivation.

**Red light (swap intensity for easy ride or rest):** Multiple nights of poor sleep, elevated resting HR, body feels broken, high life stress.

**The rule:** Recovery is not weakness. Training when you're buried just makes you more buried.

blocks.prompt: It's Tuesday. Your plan calls for 3×15 min threshold intervals. You slept 5 hours last night, work was brutal, and your legs feel like concrete. Your resting HR is 8 bpm above normal. What do you do?

options.label: Execute the workout as written — consistency matters
options.result: Bad call. You're piling fatigue on top of fatigue. The workout quality will be terrible, recovery will be compromised, and Wednesday's session is now ruined too. Consistency matters, but not at the cost of digging a hole.

options.label: Swap to an easy Z2 ride for 60 minutes
options.result: Good call. Multiple red-light signals (poor sleep, elevated resting HR, high stress) mean your body needs recovery, not more stress. An easy spin keeps blood flowing without adding training load. Tomorrow you might feel better and can execute then.

options.label: Do the intervals but at G Spot intensity instead of threshold
options.result: Better than full threshold, but still questionable. With that many red-light signals, even moderate intensity might dig a deeper hole. The safer call is full rest or very easy riding. Save the intensity for a green-light day.

blocks.question: During a threshold interval set, your power on interval 3 drops to 88% of target despite maximum effort. What should you do?

options.text: Push harder and finish the set — mental toughness matters
Stop the set — power dropped >10%, quality beats quantity
Add an extra interval at the end to make up for the weak one

blocks.explanation: When power drops more than 10% from target, you're accumulating junk volume, not building fitness. Four quality intervals at target power beats six degraded intervals. Stop, cool down, and recover for the next session. This is discipline, not quitting.

blocks.content:
The workout ends when you get off the bike. Recovery starts immediately.

**Immediately After (0-30 minutes):** Refuel if session was long (>2.5 hours) AND hard. 20-30g protein, 60-120g carbs, liquid is fine.

**That Evening:** Real dinner with adequate carbs + protein. Screen curfew 60-90 min before bed. Same bedtime every night. Dark room, cool temperature, no alcohol.

Training gives you permission to recover well, not permission to trash recovery.

For the fuel side of recovery and performance, see [Chapter 5: Nutrition & Fueling](#nutrition-fueling).

You can have perfect training, a dialed bike, and excellent pacing strategy. None of it matters if you run out of fuel halfway through your race.

Nutrition is the third most important variable after fitness and pacing (see the [hierarchy of speed](#what-is-gravel-racing)). It determines 8% of your race result. That's enough to separate finishing strong from crawling to the line.

Here's the depressing truth: many athletes never reach their potential despite doing everything right in training except for one massive detail—their nutrition sucks. Maybe they're underfueled (common) or afraid of carbs (common) or their timing is off (very common). Whatever the issue, most athletes seldom eat to support their training in a way that maximizes execution and adaptation.

**Protein** rebuilds muscle tissue damaged during training. Spread it across the day: four meals with 25-40g each beats one massive post-workout shake.

**Carbs** fuel high-intensity work and restock glycogen. Match carb intake to training load.

**Fat** supports hormones, cell membranes, vitamin absorption. Keep it moderate and consistent.

blocks.title: Your Daily Nutrition Calculator
blocks.description: Enter your weight and training day type to see personalized macro targets.

blocks.content: For any ride over 90 minutes at moderate-to-high intensity, you need 60-80g of carbohydrates per hour. Not 30g. Not 100g. 60-80g.

blocks.caption: Workout-Specific Fueling
rows: Real food works great—PB&J, bananas, bars. Practice eating solids.
Start fueling at 30-45 minutes, not 90 minutes. Mix liquids and solids.
Maybe one gel mid-session. Don't overthink this.
Test different products. Figure out what your stomach tolerates at race pace.

blocks.title: Workout Fueling Calculator
blocks.description: Plan your fueling based on workout duration and intensity.

blocks.content: Your gut is trainable just like your muscles. If you never eat during training rides, your gut won't tolerate eating during races.

steps.label: Weeks 1-4 (Base Phase)
steps.content: Practice eating real food on easy rides. 40-50g carbs per hour, mostly solid. Build tolerance gradually.

steps.label: Weeks 5-8 (Build Phase)
steps.content: Increase to 60-70g carbs per hour. Mix of liquids and solids. Practice eating at tempo pace.

steps.label: Weeks 9-10 (Peak Training)
steps.content: Hit 70-80g carbs per hour. Race nutrition only (gels, drink, bars you'll use on race day). Practice at race pace.

steps.label: Race Week
steps.content: Stick with what worked in training. No new products. Trust your gut (literally).

steps.label: Pre-Race (3-4 hrs before)
steps.content: 2-3g carbs/kg bodyweight. Low fat, low fiber. Familiar foods only. 500ml water with meal.

steps.label: Starting Line (30-60 min before)
steps.content: One gel (24g carbs) with 200ml water. Tops off blood glucose.

steps.label: 0-30 Minutes
steps.content: Focus on pacing, positioning, settling in. Sip on drink. Heart rate is spiking, gut blood flow is reduced.

steps.label: 30-60 Minutes
steps.content: First gel or equivalent (24g carbs). Start your fueling clock. Hydrate consistently.

steps.label: Every 45-60 Minutes After
steps.content: Consume 60-80g carbs per hour consistently. Set a timer. Your brain will be stupid. It will forget to eat.

blocks.content: Set a timer. Seriously. Your brain will be stupid. It will forget to eat. It will lie to you and say "I'm fine, I'll eat at the next aid station." The timer removes decision-making.
Most race nutrition failures fall into four predictable categories. Recognizing them before race day is the difference between finishing strong and crawling to the line.

items.title: The Optimist
items.content: "Aid stations will have what I need." They won't, or they'll run out. The first 500 riders cleaned out the bananas and Coke at aid station 3. You're rider 1,200. Assume aid stations have nothing you need. Carry enough fuel between stations even if they have everything.

items.title: The Minimalist
items.content: "I'll just eat when I'm hungry." By the time you're hungry, you're already glycogen-depleted. Hunger is a late-stage bonk signal. Fuel by the clock, not by feel. Set a timer for every 20 minutes. Eat something every time it goes off. No negotiation.

items.title: The Experimenter
items.content: "Let me try this new gel flavor on race day." Your gut under race stress is not the time to experiment. That mystery gel from the aid station? Your stomach will rebel at mile 60. Race with exactly what you've trained with. Nothing new on race day. Ever.

items.title: The Denier
items.content: "I don't want to carry that much food." Math check: a 100-mile race takes 6-8 hours. At 75g carbs/hour, that's 450-600g total—roughly 18-24 gels or equivalent. Yes, that much. Most people bring half that and wonder why they bonk at mile 80.

cards.back: 50-100g carbs. Low fat, low fiber. Familiar foods only.
One gel before interval set. Pre-workout meal sufficient.
60g carbs/hour. Real food works great—PB&J, bananas, bars.
60-80g carbs/hour. Mix of gels, bars, and drink mix.
70-80g carbs/hour. Start at 30-45 min. Set a timer. No new foods.
500-1000mg/hour during long efforts. More in heat. Prevents cramping.
20-30g protein + 60-120g carbs within 30 min. Real food within 2 hours.

blocks.content: These are the lessons you learn after bonking a few times. Learn them here instead.

items.label: You can't out-train bad nutrition
items.detail: Fancy intervals, perfect periodization, optimal recovery—all meaningless if you're systematically underfueling. If your training is inconsistent or you're constantly fatigued, audit your nutrition before blaming the plan.

items.label: The timer rule prevents 90% of bonking
items.detail: Set a timer for every 20 minutes during long rides. When it goes off, eat something. No negotiation. This single habit prevents the vast majority of bonking incidents.

items.label: Flavor fatigue is real
items.detail: Eating the same gel flavor for 6 hours will make you gag. Rotate through 3-4 different flavors and include real food (rice cakes, PB&J) as a palate cleanser.

items.label: Sodium saves races
items.detail: More races are lost to electrolyte imbalance than to lack of fitness. Cramping, nausea, "feeling off"—usually sodium deficit. When in doubt, take a salt tab. Worst case, you pee out the extra.

items.label: Race pace fueling is different
items.detail: What works at Z2 endurance pace might not work at race pace. Your gut behaves differently under stress. Do at least 2-3 race simulation rides where you practice fueling at race intensity.

blocks.question: You're 4 hours into a 7-hour gravel race. You realize you've only consumed about 40g carbs/hour instead of your planned 75g. You're starting to feel foggy. What's the best response?

options.text: Double your intake immediately to make up the deficit
Drop to Z1-Z2, consume 2-3 gels with water over the next 20 minutes, then gradually increase pace while maintaining proper fueling rate
Push through — you've made it this far, the deficit isn't that bad

blocks.explanation: Mental fog at hour 4 is early-stage bonk. You can't make up a massive deficit instantly (your gut can only absorb so much), but you can catch it before it becomes catastrophic. Slow down to reduce glycogen burn, get calories in fast, then resume at proper fueling rate. Doubling intake risks GI distress. Pushing through guarantees a full bonk by hour 5.

blocks.content:
Nutrition determines 8% of your race result. That's significant but not worth obsessing over.

**Daily nutrition:** Match carbs to training load. Get adequate protein. Don't fear fat. Eat real food. Research from sports nutrition scientist [Asker Jeukendrup](https://www.mysportscience.com/) consistently shows that training the gut to tolerate higher carb intake translates directly to race performance.

**Supplements:** Vitamin D if deficient, creatine for high-intensity work, caffeine before hard sessions. Everything else is optional or snake oil.

**During training:** Practice eating 60-80g carbs per hour on long rides. Train your gut like you train your legs.

**Race day:** Eat a familiar pre-race meal 3-4 hours before. Start fueling at 30-45 minutes. Hit 70g carbs per hour. Set a timer.

When your stomach rebels, back off intensity for 10 minutes and switch to liquids. Don't stop eating entirely.

Weight management happens in the off-season, not during training blocks. Chase performance, not scale numbers.

Up next: [Chapter 6](#mental-training-race-tactics) covers the mental tools and tactical framework you need when the race gets hard—because it will.

chapters.title: Mental Training & Race Tactics
chapters.subtitle: Or: How to Race Smart When Everything Hurts

blocks.content:
Physical training builds the engine (see [Chapter 3](#training-fundamentals) and [Chapter 4](#workout-execution)). Mental training determines whether you use that engine when things get hard.

And in any race measured in hours, things will get hard. Your body will hurt. Your motivation will waver. You'll wonder why you signed up for this. These moments are predictable.

The techniques in this chapter aren't abstract psychology—they're practical tools that work during racing. But like any skill, they require practice. You wouldn't show up to a race without training your legs. Don't show up without training your head.

This chapter covers two connected topics: the mental tools you need, and the tactical framework for deploying them across a long gravel race.
Mental training has five layers. Each builds on the previous one. Master them in order.

items.label: Breathing & Presence
items.detail: The foundation. Controlled breathing calms your nervous system and brings focus to the present moment. Without this, nothing else works.

items.label: Reframing
items.detail: Change your internal story. Instead of "this hurts" → "this is my body adapting." Instead of "I can't do this" → "I'm doing it right now. One pedal stroke at a time."

items.label: Anchoring
items.detail: Physical cues that trigger your race mode. Hands in the drops, core engaged, smooth pedal stroke. Match cadence to breath. These create flow state on demand.

items.label: Acceptance
items.detail: You signed up for this. Discomfort is part of the deal. Accept it. Don't fight it. Work with it. Pain is temporary. Quitting lasts forever.

items.label: Purpose
items.detail: Remember your why. Connect to your deeper motivation. This race matters because you chose it. When everything else fails, purpose keeps you pedaling.

blocks.content:
This is a simple technique for controlling your arousal state—how activated or calm you feel. It works by stimulating the parasympathetic nervous system, which counteracts the fight-or-flight response that makes you panic or tense up.

**The pattern:** Inhale for 6 seconds, hold for 2 seconds, exhale for 7 seconds.

The key is that the exhale is longer than the inhale. This is what triggers the calming response. The exact numbers matter less than the principle: long exhale, short inhale.

items.title: When to use it
items.content:
**Pre-race anxiety.** The night before or morning of the race, when your mind is racing and your heart rate is elevated despite sitting still. 3-5 cycles of 6-2-7 breathing will calm your nervous system.

**Mid-race panic.** When things feel out of control—you're dropped from your group, you just flatted, the pain is overwhelming. 6-2-7 breathing resets your state so you can think clearly.

**After a bad section.** After a crash, a mechanical, or a period of suffering where you lost time or position. 6-2-7 breathing helps you process it and move on instead of dwelling.

items.title: How to practice
items.content:
Start with 5 minutes daily, sitting quietly. Just breathe. Count the rhythm. Feel the calming effect.

Then practice during easy rides—prove to yourself you can do the breathing pattern while pedaling.

Eventually, practice during hard efforts. You should be able to do 6-2-7 breathing even when working at threshold. It's harder, but possible, and that's when you need it most.

By race day, the technique should be automatic. You shouldn't have to think about the mechanics—just trigger it when needed.

blocks.content: Don't wait until mile 100 to try 6-2-7 breathing for the first time. Practice during training so it's automatic during racing.

Your internal monologue affects your performance. When you catch yourself thinking "I can't do this" or "this is too hard," those thoughts become self-fulfilling prophecies. Your brain interprets them as permission to quit.

Performance statements are pre-planned phrases that replace negative self-talk with useful direction. They redirect your attention from suffering to action.

Write 3-5 statements now, while you're not suffering. Memorize them. Practice them during training rides. Test them during hard workouts. By race day, they should be immediately available when you need them.

tabs.label: Technical Cues
tabs.title: Technical Cues
tabs.content:
Focus on execution rather than pain. Give your brain something productive to do instead of focusing on suffering.

**Examples:**
- "Smooth pedal stroke."
- "Relax your shoulders."
- "Light hands on the bars."
- "Eyes up, look ahead."

These work because they redirect attention from suffering to action. Your brain can focus on execution or pain, not both.

tabs.label: Pain Responses
tabs.title: Pain Responses
tabs.content:
Acknowledge difficulty without surrendering to it. Reframe suffering as expected rather than catastrophic.

**Examples:**
- "This is supposed to be hard."
- "If you keep pedaling, you'll get there."
- "Pain is temporary, quitting is permanent."
- "This is what you trained for."

Some people respond to aggressive language ("Harden up"), others to calm language ("You're okay, just keep moving"). Pick what works for you.

tabs.label: Process Statements
tabs.title: Process Statements
tabs.content:
Keep you focused on the next achievable goal rather than the overwhelming total. Break the race into manageable chunks.

**Examples:**
- "Just get to the next aid station."
- "One more climb."
- "Next mile marker."
- "Pedal to that tree, then reassess."

These work because the human brain handles immediate challenges better than distant goals. "Finish the race" is overwhelming at mile 80. "Get to the next turn" is achievable.

blocks.content:
Visualization is a well-documented performance tool. But it works best when it's personal and specific, not generic imagery of "success."

A highlight reel is a mental movie you can play to access confidence and motivation on demand. It's built from your actual experiences and your specific race goals.

Do it in first person—through your own eyes, not watching yourself like a movie. Include as much sensory detail as possible: what you see, hear, feel in your body, smell. The more sensory channels you activate, the more powerful the visualization.

steps.label: Scene 1: Past Moment of Strength
steps.content: Recall a specific time when you overcame something difficult, proved yourself, or succeeded against odds. Not a vague memory—a specific moment with details. Where were you? What did it feel like? Who was there? How did you feel afterward? Make this vivid.

steps.label: Scene 2: Future Crucial Moment
steps.content: Visualize a specific section of your upcoming race where you see yourself executing perfectly. Maybe it's climbing a specific hill with your group. Maybe it's the final 20 miles when others are fading. See yourself strong, in control, handling it well.

steps.label: Scene 3: Crossing the Finish Line
steps.content: In full detail. What you see, what you hear, what you feel in your body, the emotions. Make this so vivid you can almost taste it. Practice until you can trigger the confident, motivated feeling on demand.

blocks.content: Practice visualization race morning before getting out of bed. 5-10 minutes of your highlight reel sets the tone for the day. During the race, it takes 30 seconds to run through and access a mental boost when motivation sags.

sections.title: The Three-Act Structure of Long Gravel Races

blocks.content:
Every long gravel race follows a predictable three-act structure. Understanding this structure lets you make smart decisions when others are making emotional ones.

The specifics vary by race—some front-load the climbing, some back-load it, some are flat. But the psychological and physiological patterns are consistent across all long events.

Here's how it plays out, and what your job is in each phase.

blocks.caption: The Three-Act Structure
rows: High energy, adrenaline, everyone goes too hard. Groups form. Positioning matters.
Stay calm. Don't chase. Fuel early (first 30 min). Find your rhythm. Let the race come to you.
The real race. Fatigue sets in. Groups break up. Mental game begins. This is where races are won or lost.
Stay consistent. Fuel every 20-30 min. Manage effort (don't redline). Use mental techniques. One section at a time.
Everything hurts. Decision fatigue. Final push. This is where training pays off.
Empty the tank. Use everything you've got. Remember your why. Push through the pain. Finish strong.

items.title: Act 1: The Start — The Madness (Opening 10-15%)
items.content:
The first 60-90 minutes of any gravel race is chaos. Fresh legs meet nervous energy meet a crowded course. People who trained alone all winter suddenly realize they're uncomfortable in groups. People who didn't do the work try to hang with people who did.

Attacks fly. Groups form, then shatter, then reform. The pace is erratic. Someone surges on every climb. The whole field is making decisions based on adrenaline and ego rather than strategy and fitness.

**Your job in this phase is simple: survive.**

Don't try to win the race in the first hour. You can't. But you can definitely lose it. Chasing attacks you can't sustain. Riding too hard to stay with a group that's going to explode in another 20 minutes. Forgetting to eat and drink because you're focused on positioning.

Find a group moving at a pace that feels sustainable to you—not exciting, not easy, sustainable. Settle in. Eat. Drink. Let others burn matches.

The riders making huge efforts to get to the front in the first 30 minutes? Most of them will fade. Let them go. You'll see them again later, and they'll be hurting.

items.title: Act 2: The Grind — False Dawn (Middle 50-60%)
items.content:
After the initial chaos settles, order returns. Groups stabilize. Pace becomes more predictable. The race can start to feel manageable, even easy.

Don't be fooled. This is the setup for phase three.

This is the phase where good execution means staying disciplined about nutrition and hydration. Your body doesn't hurt yet. You feel fine. It's tempting to skip a gel or wait longer between drinks. Don't.

This is also the phase where you contribute to your group's pace line, but you don't take hero pulls. Pull through, do your share, but don't try to impress anyone. Save that energy.

Watch for riders who are overworking—taking pulls that are too long, going to the front too often, breathing harder than they should be. They're making withdrawals they'll pay for in phase three.

You want to exit this phase feeling good but not great. Fresh but not antsy. If you're bored, that's perfect. Boredom in phase two means you're executing correctly.

items.title: Act 3: The Finish — The Piper (Final 25-30%)
items.content:
This is when the bill comes due. This is the race.

Under-fueled riders bonk. Their pace craters. They go from holding 18mph to struggling to hold 12mph. You'll pass them.

Under-prepared riders cramp. Their legs seize up. They're forced to slow down or stop.

Mentally weak riders quit. Not literally abandon—though some do. But mentally they check out. They're just surviving, not racing anymore.

If you've done the work—the training, the nutrition practice, the mental preparation—this is where you move up. You're not attacking. You're not surging. You're just maintaining your pace while others lose theirs.

**Watch for riders who are struggling:**
- Pace dropping noticeably
- Dropped off groups and riding alone
- Weaving slightly (sign of bonking)
- Labored breathing out of proportion to pace

Move past them steadily. Don't attack past them—just maintain your pace and roll by. Save your energy for the riders who are still strong.

This phase is a war of attrition. The question isn't who's fastest—it's who did the best job of managing the first two phases.

blocks.content: The race isn't won in the first hour, but it can be lost there. Survive phase one. Execute phase two. Capitalize in phase three.
Drafting in a group saves 20-30% energy on flats. But the wrong group can destroy your race. Here's how to think about it.

blocks.prompt: You're 30 miles into a 100-mile race. Your group is surging constantly — the pace spikes to 110% FTP on every small rise, then drops to 70% in between. You feel good now, but this pattern is burning matches. What do you do?

options.label: Stay with the group — the draft is worth the surges
options.result: Risky. Repeated surges above threshold drain glycogen stores far faster than steady-state riding. The 20-30% draft savings are negated if you're going anaerobic every 5 minutes. You'll pay for this at mile 70.

options.label: Let the group go and ride your own steady pace
options.result: Smart play. Riding at YOUR sustainable pace (G Spot range, 88-92% FTP) preserves glycogen and keeps fueling manageable. You'll see many of these riders again when they fade in the final third. Solo is fine — focus on YOUR race.

options.label: Attack to break up the surging and force a steadier pace
options.result: Worst option. Attacking costs the most energy of all and there's no guarantee the group follows your pace. Now you're solo AND you've burned a big match. Save your matches for the final 30%.

blocks.content: When things go sideways (and at some point they will), follow protocol instead of panic. Pre-planned responses beat real-time decision-making when your brain is running on fumes.

items.title: Flat Tire
items.content:
1. Stay calm—flats happen, this is not a crisis
2. Flip bike or lean against hip
3. Check if sealant is working (spin wheel, look for bubbles)
4. If hole visible, insert plug immediately
5. If plug fails or sidewall cut, replace tube
6. Reinflate to race pressure
7. Spin wheel to verify no rub
8. Resume at Z2 for 2-3 minutes to settle back in

items.title: Dropped from Group
items.content:
1. Don't panic—emotional response costs more energy than you have
2. Assess honestly: were you overextended or did they surge?
3. Find YOUR sustainable pace (probably Z2-low Z3)
4. Look for riders at similar pace within 30-60 seconds
5. Form new working group if possible—communicate intentions
6. If solo, accept it—focus on YOUR race, not theirs
7. Use solo time gaps to fuel and recover without group pressure

items.title: Bonking
items.content:
1. STOP pushing hard immediately—don't try to push through
2. Sit down if possible (don't stand around)
3. Consume 2-3 gels or 200-300 calories FAST
4. Wait 15-20 minutes MINIMUM
5. Let sugar hit bloodstream—this takes time, be patient
6. Drink 16oz water with gels
7. Resume at Z1-Z2 pace ONLY
8. Fuel aggressively for next hour to rebuild glycogen stores

items.title: Cramping
items.content:
1. Consume sodium (salt tabs or pretzels/chips) + 16oz water immediately
2. Stretch gently—don't force it or you'll tear muscle fibers
3. Drop to Z1-Z2 for 10-15 minutes minimum
4. Back off intensity by 10-15% even after cramps resolve
5. Continue aggressive sodium intake rest of race
6. Don't resume hard efforts until cramping completely resolved

blocks.content: Long races have predictable psychological phases. Knowing when they tend to show up makes them easier to handle. The specific mile markers vary by race distance, but the pattern is remarkably consistent.

steps.label: The Honeymoon (15-30% of race)
steps.content: Everything feels easy. Legs are fresh. Groups rolling smooth. HUGE temptation to go hard and "get ahead." DON'T. This is the setup for the dark patch later. Stay disciplined now, dominate later. Patience wins long gravel races.

steps.label: The Shattering (40-55% of race)
steps.content: Terrain and fatigue blow apart groups. You'll see attacks fly. People will drop. Stay disciplined. DO NOT chase efforts you can't sustain. The real race hasn't started yet. Save your matches for when they matter—the final third.

steps.label: The Dark Patch (60-75% of race)
steps.content: Where motivation dies. You've been out here for hours. Everything hurts. The finish still feels impossibly far. This is EXPECTED—not a crisis, not unique to you. Use your performance statements. 6-2-7 breathing. Keep. Moving. Forward. One pedal stroke at a time.

steps.label: Second Wind (75-85% of race)
steps.content: Often happens after an aid station or a psychological milestone ("only 30 miles left"). Body and mind reset briefly. Energy returns. Capitalize on this window—it doesn't last forever. This is your time to move up through the field.

steps.label: Late-Race Relief (85-95% of race)
steps.content: Light at end of tunnel becomes real. The finish is close enough to taste. Bodies hurt but minds lift. Use this energy surge wisely. This is where you collect rewards from earlier discipline. Push through—you've earned this.

blocks.content: Your job: Recognize these moments as part of the script, not proof that you're failing. Stay on task, solve the next problem, and let the course come back to you.

blocks.title: Integrating Mental Tools on Race Day

steps.label: Race Morning (before getting up)
steps.content: Run through your highlight reel. 5-10 minutes of visualization. See yourself succeeding. Feel it.

steps.label: Race Morning (after waking up)
steps.content: 6-2-7 breathing if you're anxious. Three cycles minimum. Stay calm, not amped.

steps.label: Pre-Start (last 30 minutes)
steps.content: Review your performance statements mentally. Have them ready. Check your process goals (first aid station, first hour, first big climb—not the finish line yet).

steps.label: During the Race
steps.content: Stay in process focus. Next aid station. Next climb. Next hour. The race happens in segments, not all at once. Use performance statements when suffering increases.

steps.label: Crisis Moments
steps.content: When things go wrong (and they will), follow this sequence: (1) Breathing—3-5 cycles of 6-2-7. (2) Statement—your most powerful performance statement. (3) Action—the smallest possible next step (just pedal 100 more meters, then reassess). This breaks the spiral of panic.

blocks.question: You're at the 65% mark of a long gravel race. Your group just rode away from you. Your legs ache and the finish feels impossibly far. What's the correct sequence?

options.text: Chase the group immediately before the gap grows
6-2-7 breathing → performance statement → find sustainable pace → look for new group
Stop at the next aid station and reassess whether to continue

blocks.explanation: This is the Dark Patch. It's predictable and expected. Chasing a group in a panic burns matches you don't have. Stopping breaks momentum. The breathing sequence calms your nervous system, the performance statement redirects your focus, and finding a sustainable pace keeps you moving forward. You'll pass some of those riders later when they fade.

blocks.content:
Mental training and race tactics aren't separate skills—they're the same skill applied at different scales. The breathing technique that calms pre-race anxiety is the same one that resets you after a flat tire at mile 100. The performance statements you practice in training are the ones that keep you pedaling through the dark patch.

**The mental tools:** 6-2-7 breathing, performance statements (technical, pain, process), visualization highlight reel. Practice them during training so they're automatic during racing.

**The tactical framework:** Survive phase one, execute phase two, capitalize in phase three. Recognize the predictable psychological landmarks. Follow the decision tree when things go wrong.

**The bottom line:** The race isn't won by the strongest rider. It's won by the rider who best manages their body and their brain across the entire distance. Train both.

Next up: [Chapter 7](#race-week) covers the final week before your race—how to taper, prep equipment, and arrive at the start line fresh.

chapters.title: Race Week Protocol
chapters.subtitle: Or: Don't Screw It Up Now

blocks.content:
You've trained for 11 weeks. You're fit. Your CTL is peaked. Your TSB is climbing toward positive freshness.

This is not the time to experiment, panic, or make decisions based on anxiety.

Race week is about execution, not improvement. You can't get fitter in seven days. You can only show up fresh and ready, or you can sabotage yourself with bad choices.

Your fitness is locked in. It was determined by the previous 11 weeks. Race week is administrative. You're managing logistics, protecting recovery, and arriving at the start line fresh.

The most important rule: Don't do anything stupid.

steps.label: Monday (7 days out)
steps.content: 60-90 minutes Z2 endurance. Keep legs moving, nothing hard. Optional: 3 × 1 min Z4 to keep neuromuscular system awake.

steps.label: Tuesday (6 days out)
steps.content: 45-60 minutes Z2. Maybe 2 × 3 min G Spot if you're feeling restless. Don't go hard.

steps.label: Wednesday (5 days out)
steps.content: Rest day or 30-45 minutes very easy spin. The last hard workout was 4-5 days ago. Everything now is just maintenance.

steps.label: Thursday (4 days out)
steps.content: 45-60 minutes Z2. Include 3-5 × 30 seconds Z5-Z6 (openers to keep legs sharp). Last real ride before race.

steps.label: Friday (3 days out)
steps.content: Travel day (if traveling) or rest day. Optional 30-minute easy spin if legs feel heavy.

steps.label: Saturday (2 days out)
steps.content: 30-45 minutes Z2 with 3 × 1 min Z4 openers. Course preview if racing Sunday. No heroics.

steps.label: Sunday (1 day out)
steps.content: 20-30 minutes very easy spin or complete rest. Do what's worked for you previously.

items.title: Final Bike Check (Thursday or Friday)
items.content:
**Drivetrain:** Chain clean and lubed. Shifting smooth across all gears. No chain slip under power.

**Tires:** Tubeless sealant fresh. Tire pressure set for race conditions. Check for cuts, sidewall damage.

**Cockpit:** Computer charged and mounted. Bottles/cages secure. Bento box organized.

**Wheels:** Thru-axles tight. No spoke issues. Hubs spin smoothly.

**Don't:** Install new chain race week. Change tire pressure drastically. Add new untested equipment.

items.title: Race Day Bag (Pack Friday or Saturday)
items.content:
**Essentials:** Spare tube (even if tubeless), tire plugs, CO2 cartridges (2-3) or mini pump, multi-tool with chain breaker, quick link, tire levers.

**Nutrition:** Gels, bars, chews—whatever you practiced with. Bottle with sports drink pre-mixed. Extra water bottle.

**Other:** Sunscreen, chamois cream, arm warmers/vest, rain jacket (if forecast), extra base layer.

**Race essentials:** Bib number and pins, race chip, ID and emergency contact info.

blocks.content:
**The Sleep Banking Strategy:** You can't sleep 12 hours the night before and expect to feel great. Sleep works cumulatively.

Goal: 8-9 hours per night ALL WEEK. Not just Thursday-Saturday.

Monday-Wednesday: Bank sleep. Go to bed early.
Thursday-Friday: Maintain normal schedule.
Saturday night: Accept that you might not sleep great. Pre-race nerves are normal. The sleep you banked Monday-Friday matters more than Saturday night.

Research shows that one night of poor sleep doesn't impair performance if you're well-rested going into it.
Wake up **3 hours before race start** if possible. This gives time for coffee to do its job and morning bathroom routine to complete. Everything from here is logistics, not training.

steps.label: 3 Hours Before Start
steps.content: Wake up. Coffee if you normally drink it (not the time to change habits). Breakfast: 100-150g carbs, minimal fat, minimal fiber. Oatmeal with banana and honey, bagel with jam, or white rice with a pinch of salt.

steps.label: 90 Minutes Before
steps.content: Start sipping sports drink. Begin hydrating and topping off fuel. Apply chamois cream and sunscreen.

steps.label: 60 Minutes Before
steps.content: Arrive at start area. Check in, use porta-potty. Get your head right.

steps.label: 45 Minutes Before
steps.content: Light warmup ride: 10-15 minutes easy spinning. Wake up the legs.

steps.label: 30 Minutes Before
steps.content: Final gear check: bottles filled and secured, nutrition in pockets, tire pressure verified, drivetrain sounds good. Run through your [performance statements](#mental-training-race-tactics) mentally.

steps.label: 20 Minutes Before
steps.content: Openers near the start: 2-3 x 30 seconds at race effort with easy spinning between. Gets HR up, legs awake, reminds body what fast feels like.

steps.label: 10 Minutes Before
steps.content: Roll to start line. Find your position. Deep breath.

steps.label: 5 Minutes Before
steps.content: 6-2-7 breathing if anxious. You're ready. Trust your training.

blocks.prompt: It's race morning. You slept terribly — maybe 4-5 hours of broken sleep. Pre-race nerves kept you awake. You feel groggy and anxious. What do you do?

options.label: Panic — consider DNS because you're not well-rested enough
options.result: Overreaction. One night of poor sleep doesn't significantly impair performance if you've been sleeping well all week. Research consistently shows this. The sleep you banked Monday-Friday matters more than Saturday night.

options.label: Execute your morning protocol exactly as planned, trust the sleep you banked earlier in the week
options.result: Correct approach. Pre-race insomnia is universal. Your body has plenty of stored recovery from the week. Stick to your routine: eat, hydrate, warm up, execute. Adrenaline will handle the rest once the gun goes off.

options.label: Double your caffeine intake to compensate for the poor sleep
options.result: Bad idea. More caffeine than your normal amount risks GI distress, jitteriness, and an elevated heart rate before you even start. Stick with your normal amount. Race day is not the time to change habits.

sections.title: What Not to Do Race Week

blocks.content:
This is where most people sabotage themselves.

**Don't:** Get a massage Friday or Saturday. Try new equipment. Test your fitness. Experiment with nutrition (see [Chapter 5](#nutrition-fueling) for what works). Drink alcohol. Stay up late packing or stressing. Cut weight.

**Do:** Sleep 8-9 hours every night. Follow your taper plan exactly. Eat familiar foods. Finalize logistics early. Trust your training. Stay off social media if it makes you anxious. Review your race plan. Arrive at the start line fresh, fueled, and ready.

blocks.question: It's Thursday before your Saturday race. You feel sluggish and your legs feel heavy during an easy spin. What does this mean?

options.text: You've lost fitness during the taper — do a hard workout to test yourself
This is completely normal during taper week — trust the process and keep resting
You should increase carb intake dramatically to combat the fatigue

blocks.explanation: Taper-week sluggishness is universal. Your body is adapting to the reduced training load. Glycogen stores are filling up, muscle repair is happening. The heavy-leg feeling is not lost fitness—it's stored fitness waiting to be expressed. Athletes who panic and do a hard workout Thursday destroy their race. Trust the taper.

blocks.content:
You crossed the finish line. You're done.

Or are you?

What you do in the hours, days, and weeks after your race determines whether you built fitness for the long term or just peaked once and faded.

items.label: Keep Moving (5-10 Minutes)
items.detail: Spin in Z1 after crossing the finish line. Let heart rate drop gradually. Stopping abruptly causes blood to pool in your legs.

items.label: Refuel Immediately (Within 30 Minutes)
items.detail: 20-30g protein, 60-100g carbs, 500-750ml fluid with electrolytes. Chocolate milk, protein shake with banana, or whatever the finish line has.

items.label: Rehydrate Aggressively
items.detail: You lost 1-4 liters of fluid. Drink 500-1000ml within the first hour. Add electrolytes. If pee is dark yellow by evening, keep drinking.

steps.label: Days 1-3
steps.content: Rest completely or very easy 30-45 minute Z1 spins. Muscles are damaged, cellular repair is ongoing. Don't push it.

steps.label: Days 4-7
steps.content: Easy Z1-Z2 rides, 45-90 minutes max. No intensity. No group rides. No Strava segments.

steps.label: Week 2 Post-Race
steps.content: Resume normal Z2 endurance volume (no intensity).

steps.label: Week 3 Post-Race
steps.content: Add light intensity (tempo, G Spot) if feeling good.

steps.label: Week 4+ Post-Race
steps.content: Back to normal training (if racing again soon) or transition to off-season.

tabs.label: Data Review
tabs.title: The Data Review
tabs.content:
Pull up your race file. Look at:

**Pacing:** Did you go out too hard? Did you fade in the second half? Did you finish strong?

**Power distribution:** What was your normalized power as % of FTP? Did it match your race plan?

**Heart rate:** Average HR as % of max? Did you redline early?

**Fueling execution:** Did you hit 60-80g carbs per hour? Any bonking or GI issues?

**Mechanicals:** Any flats, chain drops, failures? Could they have been prevented?

tabs.label: Honest Assessment
tabs.title: The Honest Assessment
tabs.content:
Ask yourself:

**What went well?** Pacing discipline? Fueling execution? Mental toughness? Equipment choices?

**What went poorly?** Blew up early? Under-fueled? Gave up mentally? Mechanical issues?

**What was in your control?** Training preparation, pacing decisions, fueling execution, equipment prep.

**What was outside your control?** Weather, course conditions, other riders' tactics.

Own what you could control. Learn from what went wrong. Don't make excuses for bad decisions.

tabs.label: Next Steps
tabs.title: Setting Your Next Goal
tabs.content:
**If you crushed it:** Move up a category. Target a harder race. Try longer distance.

**If you struggled:** Same category, better execution. More volume or consistency. Focus on the limiter.

**If you finished but didn't perform:** Analyze what went wrong. Adjust training approach.

One race is one data point. Don't overreact. But do learn.

blocks.content: After your last goal race of the season, you need an off-season. Not optional. Required. **4-8 weeks** depending on how long your season was.

steps.label: Weeks 1-2: True Rest
steps.content: Barely ride. Sleep a lot. Eat normally (not race volume, but don't go crazy). Decompress mentally. Your body is repairing accumulated fatigue from an entire season.

steps.label: Weeks 3-4: Ride for Fun
steps.content: Start riding again, but purely for fun. No power meter. No HR monitor. No structured workouts. Just ride because you want to. Mountain biking, cyclocross, trail running, hiking—cross-training keeps you active without the grind.

steps.label: Weeks 5+: Rebuild Base
steps.content: Gradually increase volume. Add some structure back. Maybe light intensity. Build base for next training block. Strength training (this is the time to build real strength—you can't during race season).

blocks.content: Off-season is when your body fully recovers from accumulated fatigue of an entire season. It's also when you rebuild motivation and remember why you actually like riding bikes. Skip it and you'll start your next training block already tired, less motivated, and more prone to injury.

sections.title: Long-Term Progression: Getting Faster Year After Year

blocks.content: You're not going to peak in your first season. Or your second. Real progress takes years. Here's what multi-year progression looks like.

tabs.label: Year 1
tabs.title: Year 1: Learning
tabs.content:
**Goals:** Finish your first gravel race. Learn what training consistency looks like. Figure out basic nutrition and pacing.

**Expected improvement:** Massive. You're starting from a low baseline. Everything works.

**Common mistakes:** Doing too much too soon, getting injured, burning out.

tabs.label: Year 2
tabs.title: Year 2: Building
tabs.content:
**Goals:** Increase training volume by 10-20%. Raise FTP by 5-10%. Improve technical skills. Race smarter.

**Expected improvement:** Significant. You're building on your Year 1 foundation.

**Common mistakes:** Comparing yourself to Year 1 rate of improvement, expecting linear gains.

tabs.label: Year 3-5
tabs.title: Years 3-5: Optimizing
tabs.content:
**Goals:** Fine-tune training approach. Peak for specific goal races. Podium at your level. Develop race-specific strengths.

**Expected improvement:** Incremental but meaningful. 2-5% gains year over year.

**Common mistakes:** Chasing marginal gains while ignoring fundamentals, overcomplicating training.

tabs.label: Year 5+
tabs.title: Year 5+: Maintaining and Evolving
tabs.content:
**Goals:** Maintain fitness while managing life changes. Continue improving weaknesses. Enjoy the process. Maybe age up into Masters categories and dominate.

**Expected improvement:** Small, but you're also older so maintaining is winning. At some point, age-related decline starts. Your goal shifts from "get faster" to "get slower more slowly."

blocks.content:
After you finish a race, there's often a void. You trained for months. It's over. Now what?

You need a new goal. Soon. Waiting too long leads to loss of motivation, inconsistent training, and fitness decay.

items.label: Pick a goal race
items.detail: Date, distance, location, difficulty level. Use the [Gravel God Race Database](/gravel-races/) to find your next target.

items.label: Define success
items.detail: Finish time, placement, or completion. Be realistic based on current fitness and what you learned from this race.

items.label: Work backward
items.detail: Race date minus 12 weeks = training start. Training start minus 4-8 weeks = off-season / recovery period.

items.label: Commit
items.detail: Register for the race. Tell people. Make it real. The goal isn't just aspirational—it's a commitment.

blocks.content: Burnout is real. It's insidious. And it will destroy your training more effectively than any injury.

items.title: Signs of Burnout
items.content: Training feels like obligation, not enjoyment. You dread workouts. Performance declines despite training. You're irritable and tired all the time. You get sick frequently. You can't sleep despite being exhausted.

items.title: Causes of Burnout
items.content: Training too hard for too long without breaks. Racing too frequently. No off-season. Life stress + training stress combining. Losing sight of why you're doing this.

items.title: How to Avoid It
items.content:
Take real off-seasons (not optional). Have other interests—cycling can't be your entire identity. Race sparingly: pick 2-4 goal races per year max. Mix up your riding—not everything needs to be structured. Check in with yourself: "Am I enjoying this? If not, why?"

Remember: this is supposed to be fun. Yes, it's hard. Yes, it's work. But if you're not enjoying the process at least 80% of the time, something's wrong.

blocks.question: After a successful race season (3 races in 4 months), a rider feels exhausted but wants to maintain fitness. They're considering jumping straight into another 12-week training block. What's the best advice?

options.text: Start the new training block immediately while fitness is high
Take a 4-8 week off-season with unstructured riding and cross-training before starting a new block
Reduce volume by 50% but maintain intensity to keep fitness sharp

blocks.explanation: Skipping the off-season is how athletes burn out. After 3 races in 4 months, the body has accumulated systemic fatigue—muscle damage, nervous system fatigue, immune suppression, and psychological drain. A proper off-season allows full recovery and rebuilds motivation. You'll lose some surface fitness, but it comes back quickly. What doesn't come back quickly: motivation destroyed by burnout.

blocks.content:
Let's be honest: gravel racing is objectively insane. You pay money to suffer for 6-12 hours on terrible roads in extreme conditions while destroying your body and bike. There are easier hobbies.

So why do we do this?

**Challenge.** Most things in modern life are easy. This isn't. And that's the point.

**Mastery.** Getting better at something hard is deeply satisfying. Watching your power numbers climb, your times drop, your skills improve—that's real progress you can measure.

**Community.** The gravel scene attracts interesting people. The kind who think suffering on dirt roads is a reasonable way to spend a Saturday.

**Simplicity.** For a few hours, nothing else matters. Not work, not stress, not life complications. Just pedal, eat, drink, repeat. There's a clarity to that.

**The finish line moment.** When you cross that line after hours of suffering and realize you actually did it—that feeling is worth everything that came before.

**Consistency Over Heroics.** 52 weeks of steady training beats 12 weeks of heroics followed by 40 weeks off.

**Recovery Over Volume.** If you're training 15 hours/week but always fatigued, you'd be better off at 10 hours recovering fully.

**Process Over Outcome.** You can't control race results. You can control training consistency, nutrition quality, sleep habits, pacing discipline.

**Enjoyment Over Suffering.** Gravel racing should be hard but fun. If you're miserable, adjust your approach.

You finished the race. You followed the plan. You learned something about yourself and about racing bikes on dirt.

That was one race. One training block. One season. The athletes who get fast and stay fast are the ones who show up consistently, year after year, refining their approach and building on what works.

You now have the framework: how to [choose a race](#race-selection), how to [understand training fundamentals](#training-fundamentals), how to [execute workouts](#workout-execution), how to [fuel](#nutrition-fueling), how to [race smart](#mental-training-race-tactics), how to [prepare for race week](#race-week), and how to recover.

The rest is execution.

Go ride your bike. Train smart. Race hard. Recover well.

And when you're ready, do it again.

That's how you become a gravel racer.
